choices.D: Create a label that has a retention setting of one year.
choices.A: Publish a label to the finance department.
choices.E: For each mailbox in the finance department, configure Message Delivery Restrictions.
choices.B: Create a data loss prevention (DLP) policy that uses the sensitive information type.
choices.C: For each mailbox in the finance department, configure the retention policy settings.

questions.question_text:
You have an Exchange Online tenant.
You need to ensure that the users in your company's finance department can select email messages that will be deleted automatically one year later. The solution must apply only to the finance department users.
Which two actions should you perform? Each correct answer presents part of the solution.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.

discussion.content: A and D are correct answers. You create a label and then publish it. While publishing it, you create the policy.

comments.content: It can also be achieved by Personal tags where the retention policy has to be applied to finance mailboxes. So w/o these tags, applying retention policy won't work.

Yes, create and publish is also an option.
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/compliance/create-apply-retention-labels?view=o365-worldwide

discussion.content: Correct
On the exam 11/02/2022
on exam 11-27-21

seems to me given answer is correct because you want the users to be able to select messages. Based on the section Combining retention policies and retention labels -> https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/compliance/retention?view=o365-worldwide
On the test Nov 3,2021

IMHO, the answer should be C and D.
You cannot publish a label to a mailbox.
It must first be put in a policy and the policy applied to the mailbox.

IMHO, the answer should be C and D.
You cannot publish a li

questions.answer_description:
Create a retention label and publish it to the finance department users.
Reference:
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/compliance/retention?view=o365-worldwide

questions.question_text:
DRAG DROP -
You have a Microsoft Exchange Server 2019 organization.
You need to identify which accounts in Active Directory are assigned permissions to dismount mailbox databases.
How should you complete the command? To answer, drag the appropriate values to the correct targets. Each value may be used once, more than once, or not at all. You may need to drag the split bar between panes or scroll to view content.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.
Select and Place:
//IMG//

discussion.content: Correct Answer is "Get-ManagementRole & Get-ManagementRoleAssignment" Get-ManagementRoleEntry doesn't have a -CmdLet parameter
- Get-ManagementRole - GetManagementRoleAssignment

Get-ManagementRole
Get-ManagementRoleAssignment

https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/powershell/exchange/find-exchange-cmdlet-permissions?view=exchange-ps
04/16/2022 - on the exam
on exam 11-27-21

The anwser is in the link provided... Get-ManagementRole followed by Get-ManagementRoleAssignment https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/powershell/exchange/find-exchange-cmdlet-permissions?view=exchange-ps

The answer given is correct. 
To find the roles in your environment (if any) that contain the cmdlet Get-ManagementRoleEntry -Identity *\<Cmdlet> 
Then Get-ManagmentRoleAssignment to see where this cmdlet and who is assigned to it.

agree! Please see for references https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/powershell/module/exchange/get-managementroleentry?view=exchange-ps
Get-ManagementRole
 [[-Identity] <RoleIdParameter>]
 [-Cmdlet <String>]
 [-CmdletParameters <String[]>]
 [-DomainController <Fqdn>]
 [-RoleType <RoleType>]
 [<CommonParameters>]
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/powershell/module/exchange/get-managementrole?view=exchange-ps

questions.answer_description:
Create a transport rule (or mail flow rule as they are called nowadays) to configure the message header: X-MS-Exchange-Organization-
SkipSafeAttachmentProcessing.
Reference:
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-gb/archive/blogs/office365labs/eo-atp-considerations-reports-demonstrations
questions.question_text:
You have a Microsoft 365 subscription.
A safe attachments policy that uses Dynamic Delivery is applied to all recipients who match your SMTP domains.
You need to prevent attachments from being scanned when internal users send email to one another.
What should you do?

choices.D: From the Security & Compliance admin center, modify the Service assurance settings.
choices.B: From the Exchange admin center, modify the malware filter.
choices.A: From the Exchange admin center, create a transport rule.
choices.C: From the Security & Compliance admin center, modify the safe attachments policy.

discussion.content: Correct
on exam 12/9/22
exam dated 26-jan-22
Correct

Answer is A
Action center has a new home and improved functionality. By December 1, 2020 – the action center experience will be removed from the Exchange admin center. Please use the updated experience in the Security and Compliance Center, Threat Review page to unblock restricted users and so on. Learn more about Restricted Users.

comments.content: Agree, this is where i unblock users now

discussion.content:
Non of them. Security & Compliance are now in 2 different sites, and answer should be the Defender Portal (security) and not in the Purview Portal (Compliance) 

KB: https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/exchange/troubleshoot/email-delivery/ndr/fix-error-code-5-1-8-in-exchange-online

“ Go to the Restricted users page in the Microsoft 365 Defender portal at https://security.microsoft.com/restrictedusers to unblock the account. After you unblock the account, the user should be able to resume sending messages within a few hours”

The answer should be A because we need to check whether the user is restricted. https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/exchange/troubleshoot/email-delivery/ndr/fix-error-code-5-1-8-in-exchange-online

Selected Answer: A
Answer is A

Selected Answer: A
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/security/office-365-security/removing-user-from-restricted-users-portal-after-spam?view=o365-worldwide

Selected Answer: A
Answer is A

Selected Answer: A
Answer is A

None of the options is valid, you should use the Microsoft 365 Defender portal at https://security.microsoft.com, go to Email & collaboration > Review > Restricted users. To go directly to the Restricted users page, use ttps://security.microsoft.com/restrictedusers
A is a good answer
Answer is incorrect. A is correct...
just an outdated question
Agree, A is now the answer as per previous comments
A is correct

questions.question_text:
You have a Microsoft 365 E5 subscription.
A user attempts to send an email message to an external recipient and receives the following error message: `Your message couldn't be delivered because you weren't recognized as a valid sender. The most common reason for this is that your email address is suspected of sending spam and it's no longer allowed to send messages outside of your organization. Contact your email admin for assistance. Remove Server returned '550 5.1.8 Access denied, bad outbound sender'.`
You need to ensure that the user can send email to external recipients.
What should you use?

choices.B: Data loss prevention in the Security & Compliance admin center.
choices.C: compliance management in the Exchange admin center
choices.A: Threat management in the Security & Compliance admin center.
choices.D: action center in the Exchange admin center

discussion.content: A & B. Get-Mailbox cmdlet shows the LitigationHoldDate and LitigationHoldOwner parameters.

comments.content: Did you check it on Exchange Server 2019 or on Exchange Online?

discussion.content:
Based on my lab, I would go with A&B. I enabled lit-hold on my test account professor plum. I was able to confirm the hold owner by running get-mailbox and by running the Run a per-mailbox Litigation Hold report. Professor Plum did not show up when I ran the In-Place ediscovery * hold report. 

Get-mailbox pplum|FL *lit*

LitigationHoldEnabled : True
LitigationHoldDate : 5/17/2021 1:32:49 PM
LitigationHoldOwner : admin@M365x443922.onmicrosoft.com
LitigationHoldDuration : Unlimited
PersistedCapabilities : {MYANALYTICSP2, BPOS_S_Enterprise}

Run a per-mailbox Litigation Hold report...
Search the admin audit log to determine if a Litigation Hold was enabled or disabled for a user's mailbox. Learn more

Run an In-Place eDiscovery & Hold report...
Search the admin audit log for changes made to In-Place eDiscovery searches and In-Place Holds. Learn more
A and B correct
Don’t understand when it says “ Each correct answer presents part of the solution” since A and B gives all the information required individually.

Selected Answer: AB
A and B, verified Nelson2080's comment on my own Exchange Server 2019.
C and D do not yield the required information.

Selected Answer: AB
A & B is correct

Selected Answer: AB
A & B is correct

A & B.

[PS] C:\Windows\system32>get-mailbox "ashlee pickett" | ft *lit*

LitigationHoldEnabled LitigationHoldDate LitigationHoldOwner LitigationHoldDuration PersistedCapabilities
--------------------- ------------------ ------------------- ---------------------- ---------------------
 True 4/2/2022 10:54:14 AM Administrator@Adatum.com 365.00:00:00 {}
The right answer A&D. Tested it on my Exchange Server!
Just tested it, A and B are the right answers!
A&B is the correct answer

A & D
A - per mailbox Litigation Hold report will give the user who made the change and time/date 
D - In-Place eDiscovery and Hold report will give details when the hold was placed.

comments.content: D is for In-place hold, not Litigation hold

choices.C: From PowerShell, run the Get-MailboxStatistics cmdlet.
choices.D: From the Exchange admin center, run an In-place eDiscovery and Hold report.
choices.A: From the Exchange admin center, run a per-mailbox Litigation Hold report.
choices.B: From PowerShell, run the Get-Mailbox cmdlet.

questions.question_text:
Your company has a Microsoft Exchange Server 2019 organization.
You are auditing the Litigation Hold on the mailboxes of the company's research and development department.
You discover that the mailbox of a user named User1 has a Litigation Hold enabled.
You need to discover who placed the Litigation Hold on the mailbox of User1, and when the Litigation Hold was enabled.
Which two actions should you perform? Each correct answer presents part of the solution.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.
